title: Wiiidddeeee, but works well

title: Good mouse. Could've been great.
content: I'm a huge fan of the original Burst Pro and Burst Pro Air. I have a bunch of them, in white and black. However, they usually had issues where one of the two clicks felt bad. The Titan Optical switches would sometimes feel dull, uneven, or pop loudly. It would often take multiple copies to get a good one. Sadly, the Burst II Air is no different. My left click feels great, but my right click has a bunch of pre and post travel, and makes a loud popping sound when actuated. The rear side button is also a bit mushy, with a ton of pre and post travel. The forward side button feels fine, though. I do appreciate the DPI button location as I cannot press it unintentionally, but it is still functional if needed. Like the prior Burst Pro Air, this has 2.4 using the USB dongle and Bluetooth. It has only one small LED light, which is fine with me. The software is easy to use and does not feel bloated. I just wish Roccat (now Turtle Beach) would bin their optical switches to make them feel more even, and not pop so loudly. The weight of this mouse is great, as is the shape, but the iffy switch quality makes me hesitant to fully recommend it.

title: Fine but not exceptional
content: Roccat was bought out by Turtle beach several years ago and now the brand has been shuttered, with Turtle Beach branding taking over all of their previous products. The Burst II Air is a sort of refresh of the Burst mouse that previously existed and while a fine product with good build quality, I can't help but be disappointed. The coating is fine but not the best that I've seen and the multiple connection options is a nice feature. Feet are adequate, being pure virgin PTFE and glide well enough. No issues with the sensor either, it performs well with no spinouts. But it just isn't competitive in the mouse market at this price. No high polling rate option, the plastic itself while well built, doesn't feel very premium and just feels lacking especially when you compare it to something like the Deathadder V3 Hyperspeed where it has a superior coating, high polling rate option and larger sized feet all for the same price. It just feels like Roccat/Turtle Beach are out of date in the market and not keeping pace with all the other competitors and it can't help me feeling disappointed. This isn't a bad mouse by any means but for the price, there are far far better options out there.

title: Lighter than a feather
content: I have been using the Burst Air II mouse for the last few weeks, and it has exceeded my expectations and my last gaming mouse. From the moment I started using it, I could feel the difference. At just 47 grams, this mouse is lightweight and ergonomic. The solid shell feels sturdy, and the included grip tape can be used to help maintain constant hold of the mouse during fast-paced gaming sessions. It is also extremely precise, and the DPI setting can be changed with the push of the side button. The scroll wheel is notched and has a good tactile feel. The buttons also have a nice click to them, and while using the mouse in wireless 2.4 GHz through the dongle, I have not experienced any noticeable lag or latency. The mouse can also connect in Bluetooth mode and works well; again, I did not experience any noticeable latency. When it comes to the battery life is also nice and long as it lasts approximately thirty-five to forty hours in 2.4 GHz mode. The skates also allow for nice and smooth glides across my mouse pad. Overall, this is a great gaming mouse that is built well, feels awesome, and can compete.
